learning_outcomes.description: Build a solid knowledge base of the theoretical assumptions underlying different approaches to research.
Critically review literature relevant to your project and use it to form a conceptual framework for your project.
Apply knowledge and skills to design a valid research project and choose appropriate methods to address your project aims and research questions.
Evaluate cultural and ethical issues related to research processes and design strategies to properly address them.
Use clear and concise language suitable to the conventions of academic writing in presenting your research project.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment 1 (Problem Statement and Research Plan) aims to get you started on selecting a research topic and plan for your project. You are encouraged to select a research problem for your project that you can relate to. This facilitates your utilisation of your prior knowledge and experiences. You should frame the problem into a researchable one and outline your plan to address it. You need to cite at least 10 academic references from academic journals or books. In addition, you may cite from non-academic sources (e.g., government reports, internet sources), where necessary. Please do not cite Wikipedia as academic references for your research project. The required referencing style for your in-text citation and references list at the end of your assessment is APA 7th edition referencing style. The UQ Library website has APA 7th edition referencing style guide, which also has information on how to cite non-English references, lecture notes, and power points. The word limit (1000 words) is suggestive. No penalties will apply based on the sole reason that your assessment is above or under the suggested word limit. More details of this assessment will be provided in class sessions and on Blackboard.

Note:

  1. This assessment is to be submitted via Turnitin. Submission of assessment to the course coordinator or your tutor as email attachment will NOT be accepted.
  2. Your assessment is evaluated according to the marking criteria specified in this course, NOT evaluated with reference to the achievement of other students or your performance in other courses.


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment 2 consists of 5 in-class tests to be conducted during tutorial sessions over 5 weeks, starting in Week 4 and ending in Week 9 (inclusive). No in-class test is scheduled in Week 6 because Friday of Week 6 is Good Friday Public holiday. Each in-class test weighs 6 marks. The duration of each test is approximately 30 minutes. Electronic devices, readings, and written notes are not permitted during the test. Tutors will provide hard copies of test sheet to students in their tutorial session of the week, and students submit their completed test sheet to their tutor at the end of the test time in the tutorial session.

In--class tests are in the format of short-answer questions. The question(s) of each test are based on the learning materials of a specific week including lecture notes and power points, tutorial notes and power points, and required readings that are available on Blackboard. More details of in-class tests will be provided in class sessions and on Blackboard course site.

Note:

  1. Each completed in-class test sheet is to be submitted in the tutorial session in which the test is conducted. Submission of an in-class test to the course coordinator or tutor as email attachment will NOT be accepted.
  2. Your assessment is evaluated according to the marking criteria specified in this course, NOT evaluated with reference to the achievement of other students or your performance in other courses.


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
This final assessment (Research proposal) aims to assess your ability to be a critical consumer and a knowledgeable producer of research. Your research proposal consists of three sections: 1) Introduction to the project, which states the purpose and significance of your study. 2) Brief literature review and research questions. Your literature review should be a concise and critical synthesis of previous research that functions to form a conceptual framework for your project. Your research questions should be informed by your literature review and be answerable if your proposed research project is to be carried out. 3) Methodology, which explains the design of your study, the specific methods chosen appropriate to the research topic and research questions, data collection strategies, and data analysis techniques. You are required to justify decisions made at each step of the research process. You also need to explain how cultural and ethical issues, if applicable, are addressed. This final assessment is expected to be informed by and developed from Assessment 1. However, you are allowed to work on a project for Assessment 3, which is different from that of your Assessment 1, if you wish to. You should cite at least 20 academic references from academic journals or books as scholarly support. You may include the academic references cited for Assessment 1 and they count towards the minimum 20 academic references required for Assessment 3. In addition, you may cite from non-academic sources, where necessary. Please do not cite Wikipedia as academic references for your project. The required referencing style for your in-text citation and the references list at the end of your assessment is APA 7th edition referencing style. The UQ Library website has APA 7th edition style guide, which also has information on how to cite non-English references, lecture notes and power points. The word limit (2000) is suggestive. No penalties will apply based on the sole reason that your assessment goes above or under the suggested word limit. Further information on this assessment will be provided in class sessions and on Blackboard.

Note:

  1. This assessment is to be submitted via Turnitin. Submission of assessment to the course coordinator or tutor as email attachment will NOT be accepted.
  2. Your assessment is evaluated according to the marking criteria specified in this course, NOT assessed with reference to the achievement of other students or your performance in other courses.


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

This first lecture provides an overview of the course structure, learning objectives, activities, requirements, assessments and other important course related information.


Learning outcomes: L01

Tutorials start in Week 2.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2 Lecture: Turning Ideas into Research Projects

This lecture discusses how to turn ideas into research as well as identifies various challenges that you may encounter when planning for a research project.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2 Lecture: Turning Ideas into Research Projects This lecture discusses how to turn ideas into research as well as identifies various challenges that you may encounter when planning for a research project.

This lecture focuses on searching for literature, critically reviewing previous studies, and developing research questions for your project.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

This lecture explores how qualitative and quantitative approaches can complement each other in mixed methods design.

learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4 Tutorial: Enhancing Trustworthiness of your Research This tutorial discusses how you can enhance the trustworthiness of your research design and findings.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5 Lecture: Knowing Research Ethics

This lecture introduces ethical principles for conducting academic research, including ethical issues related to data collection, data analysis, data storage, and data reporting.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5 Lecture: Knowing Research Ethics This lecture introduces ethical principles for conducting academic research, including ethical issues related to data collection, data analysis, data storage, and data reporting.

This tutorial discusses the ethical issues you need to consider in designing and conducting your research project.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 5 Tutorial: Applying Ethical Principles in Research
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5 Tutorial: Applying Ethical Principles in Research This tutorial discusses the ethical issues you need to consider in designing and conducting your research project.

learning_activities.topic:

This lecture introduces survey methods in collecting data from people and discusses common challenges for researchers when they use survey methods in their research.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6 Lecture: Researching on People - Survey This lecture introduces survey methods in collecting data from people and discusses common challenges for researchers when they use survey methods in their research.
